title: Carefever
author: Carefever
content: If you use a passphrase - you need to store it separately from the seed, otherwise it defeats the purpose of a passphrase. That's what best practices say.But you also need to have >1 backup of both in case one of them become rekt. That's also what best practices say.So it results in 4 locations. 1 - seed 1st backup,2 - seed 2nd backup,3 - passphrase 1st backup,4 - passphrase 2nd backup.I don't believe average hodler stores a seed + passphrase in 4 houses. So what's your approach?

comments.author: Don Pedro Dinero
comments.body: Quote from: Carefever on March 15, 2025, 09:58:54 AMI don't believe average hodler stores a seed + passphrase in 4 houses. So what's your approach?Two different locations is enough for me. The passphrase does not need to be written down, in which case you can rely on your memory, unlike the seeds. In any case, if you want a hint or to leave it written down, you can also do it in the same house but in a different place.You're also talking about the average holder, who is likely to have considerably less than 1 bitcoin. In that case, 1 HW and the seed in two different secure locations is more than enough.

comments.body: Average holders hold their coins in centralized exchanges and save their login credentials in notepad.Someone who choose to hold coins in non custodial wallet is already a minority, not to mention who understand with passphrase, saving in multiple locations etc.If you have 4 backups, it doesn't mean you have to split it to 4 houses, just place one in your room and outside your house let's say house yard, you hide your backup inside your flower pot.

comments.author: Carefever
comments.body: @Don Pedro Dinero, Memory can serve as an additional backup, but I'd not rely on it. Even if you often use HW or passphrase is short (attacker might try to bruteforce it after seed obtained).Quote from: Don Pedro Dinero on March 15, 2025, 10:17:36 AMsame house but in a different place2 locations inside each of 2 houses - seems good.I'd also put passphrase inside pm (password manager) vault where you store your other passwords. So it's accessible while you remember pm's master password which you probably re-type more often than seed's passphrase.Then you have pm's vault backup on 2 flash drives -> flash memory is not the most reliable -> but it's fine as you have passphrase and the most important passwords on paper too.

comments.author: headingnorth
comments.created_time: March 15, 2025, 11:53:33 AMLast edit: March 16, 2025, 05:09:29 AM by headingnorth
comments.body: My passphrase strategy is to first write it down...but then I will memorize it totally in my head. You can do this by first carefully choosing a good passphrase. But DON'T rely on just your memory at first.A good passphrase should be simple enough for you to memorize, but not too simple that it could be easily guessed by someone else. And not  too complicated that it can be difficult for you to recall from memory.So choose something that is very personal to you, for example the name of your favorite teacher in school + the class that they taught + year of your graduation.It could be the name of your first crush or first girlfriend/boyfriend + where you met, name of your first child and their favorite song, or your first pet and so on.That is why it is called a pass-PHRASE. Using a combination of words and/or numbers that are very personal to you makes it virtually impossible for a hacker to use a dictionary attack to guess your secret phrase. I would say a minimum of two words/numbers and maximum of four words/numbers is adequate for most. Then what you do is write down the passphrase on a piece of paper or other physical medium. Then about once a week or once a month you test yourself to be sure you can recall the passphrase without looking at the answer that you wrote down.Keep doing this self-testing over and over again for a period of several weeks or months until it is so deeply ingrained in your memory that you know it as well as you know your own name, until you feel comfortable enough to permanently discard your written physical backup.Even if you never discard your physical backup you should still practice the self-testing once a day, week or month,so in case you ever lose your physical backup you will still have it ingrained in your memory.

comments.author: pinggoki
comments.body: 4 is over the top, if you really want to hide what you have and not to worry too much about it even if people were to see it, why not try steganography? That way, you can easily leave it wherever and not worry that someone might steal what you've got, there's a lot of tutorials out there that can help you out with this one but if you are the kind that's really careful, two separate locations for your passphrase and seed is probably enough. Shutting up about owning bitcoin will probably work for you too, if they don't know that you own bitcoin then it's less likely that people with ill-intentions are going to ever target you.

comments.body: Well you see, you don't actually need to write down your passphrase - it's supposed to live inside your head. Not even in a password manager. If you forget the passphrase then that's why the seed phrase is written down.You should make multiple copies of the seed phraee and keep backups of them.

comments.author: CryptSafe
comments.body: Ordinarily, it is good that one try memorise their seed phrase at least to some extent so they could be able to recall whenever they are in need of it but the truth is that there is every possibility of one forgetting their pass phrase as it is that sometimes the need to use different wallets arises for some reasons and purpose best known to one. On that note, it is best to write down pass phrase were you can easily access it whenever the needs arises. One thing I have known over the years is that we humans we had so many things running on our mind so the tendency of we forgetting our pass phrase is very high not to talk of when one has many wallet they use for different purposes.
